content.description: To the right of the Suzie boulder, a wide boulder with horizontal cracks faces the carriage road. Traverse right-to-left along the boulder.
content.location: To the right of the Suzie boulder, on a wide boulder with horizontal cracks in it.

content.description: Suzie B follows the same formula as her big sister Suzie A (V1)--great moves up a thin face, with a low crux, high top out and ankle destroying rubble at the base.  Don't miss this climb, but also don't fall unexpectedly.  Climb the right side of the face of the Suzie A boulder, from a great starting hold to the top out 15 feet above you.
content.protection: Pads, lots of them. The business is down low and the top is relatively easy, but it's pretty important that you don't fall here.
content.location:
The right side of the Suzie A boulder               

The Suzie A Boulder: 1. Suzie A Arete (V2), 2. Suzie A (V1), 2a. Suzie A Variation (V2), 3. Pucker (V2), 4. Suzie B (V0), 5. Over the Hill (V4)

content.description:
Start with your hands on the thin horizontal holds a few feet up on the left face of the Suzie A boulder.  Work directly up the face using edges, horizontals and thin feet to the top out above.  This is a great face climbing problem.  Don't miss it if you like to climb the thin stuff. 

  For a harder variation (V2) move left from the holds above the start to climb between the arete and original route to the top.
content.protection: Pads, lots of them.  The business is down low and the top is relatively easy, but it's pretty important that you don't fall here.  The book warns of the many ankles destroyed on this problem.
content.location:
A few feet right of the arete at a thin horizontal crack on the face of the Suzie A Boulder.                

The Suzie A Boulder: 1. Suzie A Arete (V2), 2. Suzie A (V1), 2a. Suzie A Variation (V2), 3. Pucker (V2), 4. Suzie B (V0), 5. Over the Hill (V4)

content.description: From two pockets 7 feet up under the roof on the south side of the Suzie A boulder, crank up to the jug.  Using the arete the difficulty drops to V1.  For a V6 variation, start from a side pull 3 feet up above a small lip, continue to the original start and finish.
content.location:
Under the small roof on the south side of the Suzie A boulder.                

The Suzie A Boulder: 1. Stannard's Crank (V3), 1a. Stannard's Crank Variation (V6), 2. Suzie A Arete (V2), 3. Suzie A (V1), 3a. Suzie A Variation (V2), 4. Pucker (V2), 5. Suzie B (V0), 6. Over the Hill (V4)

content.description: This is a fun, somewhat awkward lip traverse that involves a lot of heel hooking and slapping. It starts on the far left side of the boulder and traverses all the way right to top out on the obvious jugs at the lip of the boulder. Make sure to find the best spots on the slopers!
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter to prevent rolling down the hill
content.location: The lone boulder just across the carriage road from the Suzie A boulder. It can be easily seen from the road.

content.description:
There is a boulder behind the kiosk which faces the carriage road, with a nice flat area in front of it for placing pads.

 Traverse the boulder from right to left, stepping up (crux) and topping out on the left end.

There's nothing (or nearly nothing) to be found here that's over V4, but there are quite a few nice moderate problems to work.  Sure the landings could be a lot better on most of them, but it just serves to hold your attention.  Right?  For the most part you don't want to climb many of the problems here unless you are solid at the grade, have a brilliant spotter or carry a high jump pit on your bouldering forays.
